schedule.title: The Value of Visualization
schedule.desc: This class will provide a general introduction to visualization. What is visualization? Why is it important? What are different functions of visualization? We will answer these questions using historical examples.

readings.title: Chapter 1. What We Talk About When We Talk About Visualization, The Truthful Art, Alberto Cairo, 2016
The Value of Information Visualization
Chapter 1. Whatâ€™s Vis, and Why Do It?, Visualization Analysis and Design, Tamara Munzner, 2014

schedule.title: HTML & CSS
schedule.desc: What skills do we need for visualization development for the web? This lab will introduce HTML & CSS, the most basic building blocks for creating a web page.

readings.title: Lab 1 Preparation
Chapter 3. Technology Fundamentals (HTML, CSS only), Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
Github Guides: Hello World
Practice with JSBin, online playground for HTML, CSS, and Javascript

schedule.title: Design Principles
schedule.desc: What are general rules of thumb for good visualization design? This class will introduce several design principles for effective visualization design through diverse examples of good, bad and weird visualizations.

readings.title: Chapter 2. The Five Qualities of Great Visualizations, Truthful Arts, Alberto Cairo, 2016
Design and Redesign - Fernanda Viegas and Martin Wattenberg
readings.link: assets/readings/Design and Redesign - Fernanda & Martin - Medium.pdf

readings.title: Chapter 6. Rules of Thumb, Visualization Analysis and Design, Tamara Munzner, 2014

schedule.title: No Class - Mass of the Holy Spirit
Visual Encoding Design
schedule.desc: What are building blocks of a visualization? This lecture introduces visual marks and perceptual channels and provides a systematic way to encode an effective visualization and decode existing visualizations in the wild.

readings.title: 5. Basic Principles of Visualization, The Truthful Art, Alberto Cairo, 2016
Chapter 2. What: Data Abstraction, Visualization Analysis and Design, Tamara Munzner, 2014
Chapter 5. Marks and Channels, Visualization Analysis and Design, Tamara Munzner, 2014
The Eyes Have It: A Task by Data Type Taxonomy for Information Visualizations
On the Theory of Scales of Measurement, S. S. Stevens, 1946.

schedule.title: Introduction to Javascript
schedule.desc: How to make a web page dynamic and interactive? In this lab, students will learn basics of the Javascript language (e.g., loops and functions) and how to create an interactive bar chart.

readings.title: Chapter 3. Technology Fundamentals (Javascript only), Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
ES6 Features: Arrows, Classes, Enhanced Object Literals, Template Strings, Destructuring, Default + Rest + Spread, Let+Const, Modules only

schedule.title: Exploratory Data Analysis
schedule.desc: What do we first do when we have data? We explore the data to gain insights about the data. This lecture provides the role of visualizations for exploratory analysis beyond formal statistical modelling and testing.

readings.title: Watch 1. Tableau Public Overview (7:10)
6. Exploring Data with Simple Charts, The Truthful Art, Alberto Cairo, 2016
Exploratory Data Analysis, NIST Engineering Statistics Handbook.
From Data to Viz
Tableau Visual Analysis Best Practices

schedule.title: Introduction to SVG & D3
schedule.desc: Building a visualization requires technology beyond simple HTML, CSS, and Javascript. This lab will give an introduction to how to generate vector-based graphics and bind data to the graphics using D3.js.

readings.title: Chapter 3. Technology Fundamentals (SVG only), Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
Chapter 5. Data, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
Chapter 6. Drawing with Data, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017

schedule.title: Storytelling with Data
schedule.desc: Visualization is not just for analyzing data but for communication of it. What are strategies for telling compelling stories with data? This lecture will take a look at different types of data stories and basic design guidelines.

readings.title: Chapter 8. Pulling it all together, Storytelling with Data, Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic, 2015
Data Humanism, The Revolution will be Visualized
On Creativity and Innovation
Narrative Visualization: Telling Stories with Data, Edward Segel and Jeffrey Heer, 2010

schedule.title: D3 Scales and Axes
schedule.desc: How do we map data to pixels? Students will learn about scale functions to handle the mapping of different types of data, as well as axes to generate visual guides for reading the scales.

readings.title: Chapter 7. Scales, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
Chapter 8. Axes, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017

schedule.title: Task Analysis and Evaluation
schedule.desc: Effective visualization depends on specific tasks to be performed on. In this lecture, we will look at a formal methodology to translate high-level goals into low-level tasks, as well as different evaluation methods.

readings.title: TBD

schedule.title: D3 Update Pattern
schedule.desc: What do we do when new data comes in? This lab will tackle the general update pattern for populating new data to an existing visualization, which is at the heart of the D3 library design.

readings.title: Chapter 9. Updates, Transitions, and Motion, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
Chapter 12. Selections, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
How Selections Work, Mike Bostock, 2013

schedule.title: Interaction
schedule.desc: How can we explore complex and multi-faceted data in a limited screen space? In this lecture, we will discuss different interaction techniques that allow us to dynamically filter data and coordinate multiple views.

readings.title: TBD

schedule.title: D3 Layouts
schedule.desc: Advanced visualizations beyond simple statistical charts often require complex layouts. In this lab, students will learn to use space more effectively by experimenting with commonly used layouts.

readings.title: Chapter 13.Layouts, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
Chapter 14.Geomapping, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017

schedule.title: D3 Brushing and Linking
schedule.desc: The fundamental guiding principle for interactive visualization is "Overview first, zoom and filter, then details-on-demand". In this lab, we will implement the principle using a focus + context technique.

readings.title: Chapter 10.Interactivity, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017
Chapter 11.Using Paths, Interactive Data Visualization for the Web, 2nd Edition, Scott Murray, 2017

schedule.title: No Class - IEEE VIS Conference Travel
schedule.desc: TBD: there might be a guest lecture or visit to exhibitions in nearby libraries.

schedule.title: D3 Custom Visualizations
schedule.desc: Standard visualizations may not be able to handle the complexity of your data. This lab provides an opportunity to learn how to go out of the box and invent novel visual encodings.

readings.title: Creating a Unique Visualization
The D3.js Graph Gallery

schedule.title: Perception & Cognition
schedule.desc: Well-designed visualizations leverage human visual perception to amplify our limited cognitive abilities. We will cover a set of perception theories on colors, size estimation, preattentive processing, gestalt principles, and more.

readings.title: Perception in Visualization, Christopher G. Healey, 2012
Your Friendly Guide to Colors in Data Visualisation
39 Studies About Human Perception in 30 Minutes. Kennedy Elliott.
readings.link: assets/readings/39 studies about human perception in 30 minutes - kennedy elliott - Medium.pdf

readings.title: Graphical Perception: Theory, Experimentation and the Application to the Development of Graphical Models. William S. Cleveland, 1984.

schedule.title: D3 Multiple View Compositions
schedule.desc: To support complex tasks or to see multiple perspectives on data, we need more than one visualization. In this lab, students will learn how to coordinate multiple visualizations.

readings.title: Towards Reusable Charts

schedule.title: Networks and Maps
schedule.desc: Statistical graphics can cover tabular data but not network and geographic data. In this lecture, students will learn about specialized visualizations for graph structures and geographic maps.

readings.title: What to consider when creating choropleth maps, Lisa Charlotte Rost, 2018
Chapter 9. Arrange Networks and Trees, Visualization Analysis and Design, Tamara Munzner, 2014

schedule.title: Introduction to Vega-Lite
schedule.desc: While D3 is the Swiss army knife for custom visualizations, it is often overkill for most visualizations. This lab introduces Vega-lite that provides a higher-level grammar for rapidly generating standard visualizations.

readings.title: TBD

schedule.title: Multi-Dimensional Data
schedule.desc: Data is getting more complex and multi-structured (e.g., multivariate dynamic networks), or even unstructured (e.g., text). In this lecture, we will take a look at more complex visualizations for tables, networks, maps, and combinations of all.

readings.title: A Tour through the Visualization Zoo
How to Use t-SNE Effectively

schedule.title: Advanced Vega-lite
schedule.desc: While not as flexible as D3, Vega-lite provides several ways to create beyond simple statistical charts including cartograms and parallel coordinate plots. This lab will cover how to construct multi-view interactive displays in Vega-lite.

readings.title: TBD

schedule.title: Design Feedback Session 1
schedule.desc: Feedback is critical in the visualization design process. Student teams will present working-in-progress prototypes or sketches, and receive constructive feedback from peers.

readings.title: The 10 Bad Habits that Hurt Critique
readings.link: assets/readings/The 10 Bad Habits that Hurt Critique.pdf

schedule.title: Design Feedback Session 2
schedule.desc: Feedback is critical in the visualization design process. Student teams will present working-in-progress prototypes or sketches, and receive constructive feedback from peers.

schedule.title: Uncertainty and Interpretability
schedule.desc: Statistical models are everywhere nowadays. These models are not deterministic and generate estimates with uncertainty. This lecture will introduce visualizations to provide more credible interpretations of the models.

readings.title: The Visual Uncertainty Experience, OpenVis 2016, Jessica Hullman
Visualizing Uncertainty, Fundamentals of Data Visualization, Wilke, 2018

schedule.title: Research in Visualization
schedule.desc: Anyone can do research in visualization. The final project in this class is an example of visualization research. In this lecture, we will see what types of research exist in the field.

schedule.title: Final Project Presentation
schedule.desc: Student teams will showcase their final prototypes to the class. Presenting an idea clearly and professionally is important and will be part of the final project evaluation.
